awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Statistical Learning of Predictive Dependencies of Tense-Aspect System in the Artificial Language by English and Thai L1 Adults
awd_abstract_narration:
While many adults are keen to learn a second (L2) or additional (Ln) language because of academic, economic, or cultural reasons, their success may not come as easily as that when they acquired their first language (L1) as children. One of the reasons for this variable success is prior linguistic experience from different L1s. Moreover, the presence of multilingualism, that many adults will learn several languages over their lifetime, makes it harder to assess prior knowledge. Learning a language means becoming attuned to and developing expectations for systematic linguistic patterns, from sound sequences to grammatical relations. Successfully learning a novel language requires that adults abstract new systematic patterns from the input while using existing ones from their learned language(s). This research will help us understand language prediction and multilingual learning processes.

This dissertation research project employs an artificial grammar learning paradigm to investigate how a particular kind of probabilistic systematic pattern, predictive dependencies, in adults' existing tense-aspect system(s) can promote or prevent adaptation to novel tense-aspect regularities. Adult participants from two L1 backgrounds, English and Thai, will learn a miniature language that expresses temporal meaning involving both English- and Thai-analogous predictive dependencies at different levels: between lexical and sub-lexical items (e.g., walk+ed) for English and between lexical items (e.g., a pair of aspect markers such as sed leew ["already completed"]) for Thai. Because the same meaning in the miniature language is equally likely to appear with both sets of dependencies, this research will investigate (1) whether participants are better able to learn predictive dependencies that are consistent with their L1-analogous dependencies and (2) whether the findings will be true under bilingual learning conditions for the English participants, who have perfect knowledge of one set of dependencies and zero knowledge of the other, and under trilingual learning conditions for the Thai-English participants, who have both sets of dependencies available for use during learning but with varying degrees of statistical precision in their L2, English.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Languages differ in the way they encode time, and each language can use several grammatical means to do so. English, for example, uses systematic associations between verbs and inflectional morphemes to describe temporal meanings of completion (e.g., I just talk+ed to my boss) and continuation (e.g., he love+s chocolate) of events, that is, tense and aspect information is grammatically encoded in English. In many other languages, for instance in Thai, one or more markers are used before or after verb phrases to encode such time notions (e.g., a pair of markers sed leew ["already completed"] after a verb phrase). What are the consequences of having learned one system of encoding of time on the learning of another? We explored one scenario: Prior learning experience with one set of associations equips language learners with an expectation for such associations in a new language. This means that if a new language that learners are attempting to learn encodes time using similar systematic associations to those of their known language(s), learning of those new-language associations is likely to be facilitated. 

We tested this scenario by presenting adult language learners with a miniature language that encoded temporal meanings of completion and continuation in two ways, in a similar manner to how English and how Thai do so, independently. To illustrate, the completion meaning ‘man finish-ed a book’ was paired in the miniature language input with an English-like encoding (i.e., associations between verbs and morphemes such as harter dola katon-an) and a Thai-like encoding (i.e., associations between words such as harter dola katon lon-beng). We then exposed participants from these two first language (L1) backgrounds, English and Thai, to this “bilingual” input by having them watch animated videos and listen to sentences in the miniature language. Participants completed the experiment over four 25-minute sessions spread into two days, and at the end of each session they took a comprehension test that assessed the extent to which they gradually figured out the meanings and learned the forms, that is, the extent to which they “adapted” to the two encodings of the miniature language. In addition, the two groups of participants completed an English tense-aspect test, which assessed variable sensitivity to English tense-aspect encodings.

We carried out data analysis with Bayesian multilevel regression models, a type of statistical analysis that quantifies uncertainty surrounding an effect about which researchers are interested in learning. The results showed that participants adapted more accurately to the L1-analogous encoding, when compared to the non-analogous one, and that this was true for both the English and the Thai L1 groups. Another important finding was that the higher an English or Thai participant’s sensitivity to English tense-aspect encodings was (as shown by their scores on the tense-aspect test), the better adaptation they tended to show to the English-analogous encoding of the miniature language, although this was only a trend that will need confirmation in future research. Taken together, this research indicates that when learning a new language, adults make use of the existing systematic associations for tense-aspect encodings they know in their own language to aid themselves in their adaptation to a novel tense-aspect system of which they had no a priori knowledge.

NSF funding enabled us to collect data from two research sites, one in Washington D.C., USA and the other in Bangkok, Thailand as well as to train research assistants on data collection procedures and basic statistical analyses. The findings from the present research can lay a foundation for future research that seeks to further investigate (1) additional kinds of systematic associations underpinning temporal and other types of linguistic meanings and (2) language learners’ sensitivity to those types of information. The findings from this and future research can help inform pedagogical interventions that train learners to focus on the relevant meaningful associations between linguistic units (e.g., inflectional morphemes at the end of verbs, grammatical markers before or after a verb) in a new language, thereby helping adults learn a second or foreign language better.
